study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the usability and user feedback of a Guided Imagery Therapy (GIT) mobile app designed for children with Functional Abdominal Pain Disorders (FAPDs) and their caregivers.
results_summary: The GIT app demonstrated above-average usability, with favorable ratings from both children and caregivers. However, users reported difficulties in setting reminder notifications and suggested improvements in aesthetics, content, and gamification to enhance engagement.
population_specificity: Children aged 7-12 years with Rome IV-defined FAPDs and their caregivers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of Be Smoke Free, a telephone-delivered Guided Imagery treatment for smoking cessation, compared to standard behavioral treatment.
results_summary: As of March 2023, 242 participants were enrolled, with high follow-up completion rates (82.2% at 3 months, 93% at 6 months). Primary results on smoking abstinence will be published in 2027.
population_specificity: Adults seeking to quit smoking, recruited via quitlines and population-based methods.
study_duration: Assessments at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months post-enrollment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding Guided Imagery (GI) to a 12-week lifestyle intervention could alter diurnal salivary cortisol patterns and perceived stress in adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that the Lifestyle Behavior GI (LBGI) group showed a small increase in Cortisol Awakening Response (CAR) compared to controls, and among adherent participants, LBGI also demonstrated a moderate-large reduction in perceived stress (PSS). No significant changes were observed in Diurnal Cortisol Slope (DCS) or PSS across other intervention arms.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 14-17 years.
effective_dosage: Weekly GI sessions (exact duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Virtual Reality Assisted Guided Imagery (VRAGI) on pain management in patients with advanced cancer in a home setting, as well as its impact on opioid use, anxiety, depression, and fatigue.
results_summary: The study proposes a randomized controlled trial to compare VRAGI with other modalities, but results are not yet reported in the abstract. The primary focus is on evaluating pain reduction and secondary outcomes like opioid use and psychological distress.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced cancer recruited from Prisma Health in Greenville, South Carolina, USA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of brief guided imagery on symptoms of chronic back pain, anxiety, and daily activity in women with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that brief guided imagery significantly reduced pain (NPRS), anxiety (STAI), and improved daily activity (MOQ), but no significant change was observed in fear-avoidance beliefs (FABQ).
population_specificity: 35 women with chronic back pain treated at the Rheumatology Outpatient Clinic of Barzilai Medical Center in Ashkelon, Israel.
effective_dosage: Five brief GI group meetings every 2-3 weeks, one hour each, plus daily practice of 6 GI exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Virtual Reality (VR) and Guided Imagery (GI) on mood and biophysical parameters in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that VR was more effective than GI in improving mood states, but GI showed no significant effectiveness for nausea, pain, or feeling sick. No statistically significant improvements in biophysical parameters were noted for GI.
population_specificity: 50 cancer patients on active chemotherapy treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the procedural steps and considerations for curating a music program (Copenhagen Music Program) tailored to psilocybin sessions, using Guided Imagery and Music as a framework.
results_summary: The study presented a method for selecting and sequencing music to support the therapeutic dynamics of psilocybin sessions, introducing the Copenhagen Music Program and the Taxonomi of Therapeutic Music as tools for evaluation. It provided practical examples for music programming but did not report specific clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on psychedelic intervention contexts).
effective_dosage: Medium/high dose psilocybin (specific amount not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a brief guided imagery intervention (GIFT) to reduce radiotherapy-related anxiety and depression in patients with head and neck cancer.
results_summary: The study found that guided imagery could potentially reduce psychological distress in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy, though efficacy results were preliminary and focused on feasibility and acceptability rather than definitive outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck cancer planning to receive radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Two-session guided imagery intervention (specific details not provided).
study_duration: Brief (two sessions), with follow-up at 1 month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of tele-guided imagery on stress levels among caregivers of chronic neurological patients.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in perceived stress scale (PSS) scores among caregivers receiving tele-guided imagery compared to the control group, indicating its effectiveness for stress management and mental health improvement.
population_specificity: Caregivers of chronic neurological patients (n=30).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) and guided imagery (GI) on physical and emotional symptoms in nursing students during their initial clinical training.
results_summary: Guided imagery significantly reduced emotional symptoms (anxiety, depression, and stress) more effectively than PMR and the control condition. PMR was more effective than GI in reducing physical symptoms, though GI also showed significant physical symptom reduction compared to the control.
population_specificity: Nursing students at a large Jordanian university undergoing initial clinical training.

study_goal: To analyze the effects of virtual reality guided imagery combined with progressive muscle relaxation on vital signs in hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation patients.
results_summary: The intervention showed clinical significance in reducing respiratory rate across all stages and improved heart rate, temperature, and oxygen saturation from the 1st to the 12th measurements. It was deemed low-cost, easy to apply, and effective for patient-focused care.
population_specificity: Hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation patients in a referral hospital in southern Brazil.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of guided imagery meditation on reducing anxiety, improving sleep quality, and relieving postoperative pain in patients after laparoscopic cholecystectomy surgery.
results_summary: Guided imagery significantly reduced anxiety (F = 8.04, p = .01), improved sleep quality (F = 39.99, p = .001), and decreased postoperative pain (p = .001) compared to usual care.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from laparoscopic cholecystectomy surgery in a general surgical ward of a teaching hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether guided imagery could enhance positive future-directed thinking (FDT) in individuals with first-episode psychosis.
results_summary: Participants in the positive imagery condition generated significantly more positive future events compared to the neutral condition, with increased likelihood ratings for positive events post-intervention. Positive events were anticipated to be more positive further into the future, while negative events were perceived as more negative over time.
population_specificity: 44 individuals experiencing a first episode of psychosis with relatively low symptom levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to empirically identify indication criteria for the use of guided affective imagery (GAI) in psychodynamic therapies.
results_summary: The study reconstructed a sequential model of therapists' indicative decisions, involving contraindications (e.g., reality testing issues), modified applications (e.g., emotional instability), and patient/therapist characteristics influencing GAI use. The findings suggest a complex interplay of factors guiding GAI application.
population_specificity: Psychodynamic therapists (N=15) qualified as GAI training therapists.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of guided imagery on the quality and severity of pain and pain-related anxiety during burn dressing changes.
results_summary: The study found that guided imagery significantly reduced pain and pain-related anxiety in burn patients, with statistically significant differences observed from the second session onward compared to the control group. The effects were consistent across multiple sessions.
population_specificity: Burn patients undergoing dressing changes.
effective_dosage: Four sessions of guided imagery (one session per day for four consecutive days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and test a brief mindfulness-informed guided imagery intervention to promote physical activity enjoyment and engagement by targeting cognitive and affective processes.
results_summary: Participants found the guided imagery easy to use, enjoyable, and helpful, reporting increased physical activity frequency, enjoyment, mindfulness during exercise, self-efficacy, and satisfaction. Qualitative data indicated positive shifts in behavior, affect, and future-oriented thinking related to physical activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population of underactive individuals implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore healthcare professionals' experiences with managing countertransference using self-guided imagery in meditation (SIM).
results_summary: Participants reported that SIM helped them manage countertransference, leading to improvements in managing personal vulnerability, setting clearer boundaries, and practicing self-care. The results suggest SIM can aid healthcare professionals in dealing with unresolved inner conflicts and enhancing wellbeing.
population_specificity: Healthcare professionals caring for patients with mental illness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effects of group-delivered stress-reduction guided imagery on stress biomarkers (salivary cortisol and amylase) and self-reported stress moods in healthy, predominantly Latino adolescents.
results_summary: The guided imagery group showed a 32% decrease in salivary cortisol and significant reductions in all five self-reported stress moods (27%-46%), while the lifestyle-only group had only a 5% cortisol decrease and minimal mood improvements. No significant changes in salivary amylase were observed in either group.
population_specificity: 111 healthy, predominantly Latino adolescents (94% Latino).
effective_dosage: Weekly stress-reduction guided imagery sessions (group format).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and acceptability of the See Me Serene mHealth app, which uses guided imagery to reduce stress and anxiety related to COVID-19 and social isolation, and explore its potential impact.
results_summary: The app showed feasibility in recruitment, retention, and adherence, with participants reporting satisfaction and potential reductions in stress, anxiety, loneliness, and worry, though no significant changes in cortisol levels were observed.
population_specificity: Adults experiencing stress and anxiety related to COVID-19 and social isolation, recruited online and through university presentations.
effective_dosage: Approximately 1.6 audio files per day (48.2 over 30 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of guided imagery (GI) versus virtual reality (VR) in managing procedural pain and state anxiety in children and young adults undergoing unsedated procedures.
results_summary: GI and VR were similarly effective in managing procedural pain. GI was more effective for participants with high trait anxiety, while VR reduced nervousness about pain in those with high pain catastrophizing. State anxiety decreased significantly only during VR interventions.
population_specificity: Children and young adults (median age 13 years) with acute or chronic illnesses undergoing unsedated procedures in hematology, oncology, and blood and marrow transplant clinics.
study_duration: Administered during separate but consecutive unsedated procedures (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of combined progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) and guided imagery (GI) on stress, anxiety, depression, mood, quality of life, and chemotherapy-related adverse effects in breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The intervention was effective for reducing stress and anxiety, positively improved quality of life, but showed no significant improvement in chemotherapy-related adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients with breast cancer

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of guided imagery on anxiety, muscle pain, and vital signs in patients with COVID-19.
results_summary: Guided imagery significantly reduced state and trait anxiety, improved pain quality and intensity, and positively affected heart rate, systolic blood pressure, and oxygen saturation in COVID-19 patients.
population_specificity: 110 patients with COVID-19
effective_dosage: Ten training sessions of guided imagery (frequency not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the use and short-term outcomes of a multiple-behavior guided imagery intervention delivered via an mHealth app for pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in depression, anxiety, and stress, increased physical activity, and some changes in body image among participants using guided imagery. The Sleep and Relaxation audio file was the most widely used and favored.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (mean age 28.5 years).
effective_dosage: Daily listening to an audio file for 35 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of guided imagery in changing pain scores, anxiety scores, and opioid analgesia usage among hospitalized adults in an acute care setting.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant reductions in anxiety scores and opioid analgesia usage but no significant changes in pain scores. The intervention was feasible and showed potential as an adjunctive therapy for anxiety and opioid reduction.
population_specificity: Adult inpatients referred to an APRN-led pain management service in an acute care hospital.
effective_dosage: 30-minute guided imagery recording delivered via MP3 player, used twice daily.
study_duration: Measurements were taken at baseline, 24 hours, and 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure the effect of guided imagery and hand massage on self-rated wellbeing and pain in palliative care patients.
results_summary: The intervention led to statistically significant improvements in self-reported wellbeing (p = .029) and pain (p = .001), with participants finding it helpful and relaxing.
population_specificity: Adult palliative care patients (n = 20).
effective_dosage: One session of guided imagery and hand massage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the incremental effects of guided imagery (GI) combined with lifestyle education on dietary and physical activity behaviors in adolescents.
results_summary: Intention-to-treat analysis showed no additional effect of GI on dietary outcomes, but among adherent participants, GI (especially stress reduction GI) reduced sedentary behavior and increased moderate + vigorous physical activity, while also improving eating habits in some groups.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 14-17 years (high school sophomores or juniors).
effective_dosage: After-school sessions held 3 times weekly for SRGI and LBGI groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of guided imagery via virtual reality on health-related quality of life in patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
results_summary: The study found improvements in health-related quality of life scores, though not statistically significant, and identified significant positive correlations among quality of life, fatigue, and neutropenia across stages.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation in a Brazilian public hospital.
effective_dosage: Not specified (audio-guided relaxation with nature images in 360º during hospitalization).
study_duration: Administered during the hospitalization period (specific duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of guided imagery on reducing fatigue and stigma, and improving mood in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Guided imagery significantly reduced fatigue and stigma scores and improved mood in the intervention group compared to the control group, with all changes being statistically significant (P < 0.0001).
population_specificity: 60 patients with multiple sclerosis referred to a special diseases center in southeast Iran.
effective_dosage: 25-minute guided imagery audio file listened to at home (frequency not specified).
study_duration: One month (intervention duration unclear, follow-up at one month post-intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of guided imagery on well-being, stress, anxiety, and immune system enhancement.
results_summary: The study found that guided imagery enhances well-being, reduces stress and anxiety, and may improve immune system function, with supporting research and data.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of hypnoanalysis and guided imagery in identifying and managing emotional causes of multiple sclerosis (MS) and improving quality of life (QoL).
results_summary: The guided imagery group showed temporary improvement in 2 QoL subscales compared to hypnoanalysis, but this effect disappeared at follow-up. No changes in disability were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Fifteen participants with severe multiple sclerosis (MS).
effective_dosage: 10 group sessions of body relaxation and guided imagery, recorded for home practice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and assess program materials for a guided imagery-based smoking cessation intervention targeting underserved populations, including men and racial/ethnic minorities.
results_summary: The study incorporated feedback from small group interviews and pilot testing to refine the intervention, with participants reporting prior experience with mindfulness and meditation practices. The program was tailored to be inclusive of groups less likely to use traditional quitline services.
population_specificity: Underserved quitline populations (52.37% non-white; 55.56% men).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Brief Guided Imagery (BGI) on chronic, fibromyalgia-related pain and its impact on quality of life.
results_summary: BGI was associated with significant improvements in pain management, mood, sleep, daily functioning, and overall quality of life. The study found positive effects on pain and quality of life measures with just two-minute sessions.
population_specificity: 37 female patients diagnosed with fibromyalgia.
effective_dosage: Two minutes per session (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and acceptance of self-practiced stabilizing and guided imagery techniques via digital audio files for traumatized refugees.
results_summary: About half of the patients practiced the techniques daily, reporting improvements in arousal, concentration, sleep, mood, thoughts, empowerment, and tension. "The Inner Safe Place" technique was particularly well received, though postmigratory distress factors sometimes impeded practice.
population_specificity: Traumatized refugees living in a reception and registration center in Germany.
effective_dosage: Not specified (self-practice via digital audio files).
study_duration: Initial practice over 9 days, with follow-up at 2 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether presenting a suggestion to "sleep more deeply" as guided imagery (instead of hypnosis) would improve slow-wave sleep in low-hypnotizable participants.
results_summary: Guided imagery did not improve slow-wave sleep in low-hypnotizable participants; instead, it reduced slow-wave sleep duration and the ratio of slow-wave activity to beta band power, similar to previous hypnosis-based interventions. Subjective sleep quality remained unaffected.
population_specificity: Young, healthy, low-hypnotizable participants.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved a single pre-sleep suggestion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether guided imagery combined with breathing relaxation improves sleep quality in elderly patients undergoing abdominal surgery.
results_summary: The study found that guided imagery with breathing relaxation significantly improved sleep quality in the intervention group before and after surgery, with higher scores at 48 and 96 hours post-surgery compared to the control group. The generalized estimating equation model showed an 8.76-unit higher sleep quality score in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Elderly patients undergoing abdominal surgery in two educational hospitals in Mashhad, Iran.
effective_dosage: Guided imagery performed twice daily via audiotape along with breathing relaxation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of guided imagery on pain and fatigue in oncology patients compared to Reiki and a control group.
results_summary: Guided imagery reduced pain and fatigue in oncology patients, with similar efficacy to Reiki. The study recommends its use in oncology nursing care.
population_specificity: 180 oncology patients at Dicle University Hospital in Turkey.

study_goal: To develop and test the feasibility and potential impact of a guided imagery-based tobacco cessation intervention delivered using a quitline model.
results_summary: The guided imagery intervention was feasible to deliver, with high retention and adherence rates. Long-term quit rates (27.9% for guided imagery vs. 38.1% for behavioral control) compared favorably to quitlines, and program satisfaction was high.
population_specificity: Smokers recruited statewide through a quitline or community-based methods.
effective_dosage: Six sessions of guided imagery audio file creation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) and Guided Imagery (GI) could alter coping strategies in parents of children with malignancy undergoing active treatment.
results_summary: The study found no significant impact of PMR and GI on parents' coping strategies, as measured by the Ways of Coping Checklist (WofCC). Both intervention and control groups preferred positive coping methods, such as positive approach, re-evaluation, and prayer/daydreaming.
population_specificity: Parents of children hospitalized with malignancy in Cyprus and Greece.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether guided imagery prior to surgery reduces preoperative anxiety and acute postoperative pain in adults and children compared to conventional preoperative care.
results_summary: Guided imagery was effective in reducing preoperative state anxiety in children, preoperative trait anxiety in adults, and postoperative pain in adults. It showed some reduction in postoperative pain in children and preoperative state anxiety in adults, but these effects were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Adults and children undergoing surgery.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine critical care nurses' perspectives on Guided Imagery, including perceptions of legitimacy, knowledge, beliefs of harm/benefits, and professional/personal use.
results_summary: Nurses endorsed the legitimacy of Guided Imagery (66%-83%), showed interest in gaining further knowledge, and had positive beliefs about its benefits, though professional use was lower compared to aromatherapy and music therapy.
population_specificity: Critical care nurses (N = 53) practicing in 3 intensive care units at a Midwestern academic-affiliated medical center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of guided imagery on anxiety, depression, and chemotherapy-related side effects in cancer patients.
results_summary: Guided imagery significantly reduced anxiety and depression in the intervention group compared to the control group, with notable improvements in pain, insomnia, appetite, and nausea. No reduction in anxiety or depression was observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with various types of cancer undergoing chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes per day of guided imagery audio.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of psycho-education based on relaxation methods (including Guided Imagery) on reducing Hyperemesis Gravidarum (HG) symptoms in pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found that psycho-education based on relaxation methods significantly reduced nausea and vomiting in pregnant women compared to the control group, as measured by the PUQEEN scale (p = 0.035). The intervention group showed a lower average score (5.11 ± 1.60) than the control group (6.00 ± 1.66).
population_specificity: 100 pregnant women with complaints of nausea and vomiting attending general health centers for pregnancy care.
effective_dosage: 3 sessions of psycho-education over a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the meaning of guided imagery relaxation for women with breast cancer and explore their perceptions of cancer and their immune system during and after sessions.
results_summary: Participants' experiences were categorized into three themes: cancer stigma, facing disease, and treatment benefits, indicating that guided imagery relaxation helped them reflect on their condition and perceive therapeutic benefits. The study highlighted the importance of nurse-provided therapy in breast cancer care.
population_specificity: Women with breast cancer, aged 45-67, receiving radiotherapy at a public teaching hospital in São Paulo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and potential impact of a telephone-delivered Guided Imagery (GI) intervention for tobacco cessation compared to a standard behavioral (SB) intervention.
results_summary: The study assessed feasibility (recruitment, retention, adherence) and secondary outcomes (cessation at 6 months post-intervention). Results will determine the intervention's feasibility and reach to under-represented tobacco users, guiding future efficacy trials.
population_specificity: Smokers, with a focus on under-served minority groups and those seeking alternative cessation methods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze how emotions and imagery are shared, processed, and recognized in Guided Imagery and Music by measuring brain activity in a therapist and client during a real therapy session.
results_summary: The study found that important therapeutic moments showed different cortical activity compared to resting-state, with shifts in emotional valence and intensity. EEG data indicated synchronized emotional processing between therapist and client during key moments, such as receiving a message of hope.
population_specificity: An experienced therapist ("Guide") and a client ("Traveler") in a real therapy session about the potential death of family members.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the suitability of stabilizing techniques and guided imagery for treating traumatized refugees in unstable living conditions.
results_summary: Participants reported increased relaxation, improved psychosocial functioning, and better management of recurrent thoughts, though challenges included difficulty focusing and distractions during self-practice.
population_specificity: Traumatized refugees in a German state registration and reception center.
study_duration: May 2017 to April 2018 (exact intervention duration unclear)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of guided imagery (GI) on pain and function in individuals undergoing total knee replacement, using an audiobook (AB) as a placebo control.
results_summary: The study found that participants in the AB placebo group reported benefits like pleasant distraction and inspiration, but also experienced resentful demoralization, particularly postoperatively. The efficacy of GI relative to the placebo was not explicitly detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Persons undergoing total knee replacement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of perioperatively applied guided imagery on nausea, satisfaction, and anxiety in surgical patients.
results_summary: The study found that guided imagery significantly reduced anxiety and pain intensity while improving satisfaction and sleep quality compared to standard care alone. These results suggest guided imagery can be beneficial in managing perianesthetic symptoms.
population_specificity: Surgical patients (perioperative period)
effective_dosage: Applied once preoperatively, once on the first postoperative day, and twice on the second and third days (total of six sessions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and stress-related outcomes of a 6-week pilot lifestyle intervention using guided imagery (GI) council to reduce obesity-related disease risk factors in Latino adolescents.
results_summary: The intervention was feasible and well-liked, with a 31% reduction in salivary cortisol following stress-reduction GI sessions. No change in daily cortisol patterns was observed, but perceived stress changes correlated with cortisol awakening response changes.
population_specificity: Urban Latino adolescents (12 females/5 males, age 17 ± 1 years, grades 9-12).
effective_dosage: Three 75-minute sessions per week (nutrition education, physical activity, and GI council).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether relaxation-guided imagery could reduce preoperative anxiety and postoperative pain in children undergoing minor surgery.
results_summary: The study found that relaxation-guided imagery significantly reduced both preoperative anxiety and postoperative pain in children compared to standard care, with statistically significant differences (p < .001 for both outcomes).
population_specificity: 60 children aged 6-12 years undergoing minor surgery.
study_duration: Administered before the induction of general anesthesia (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a pre-exam guided imagery intervention could reduce test anxiety in senior baccalaureate nursing students.
results_summary: Most students demonstrated a reduction in self-reported test anxiety after the guided imagery intervention, as measured by pre- and post-intervention Likert scale assessments.
population_specificity: 49 senior baccalaureate nursing students

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the effectiveness of a home program of audio-recorded guided imagery relaxation on people with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in trait anxiety, sleep quality, and tenderness at some tender points after the guided imagery intervention. No significant differences were reported for other measured outcomes like pain, self-efficacy, quality of life, or fibromyalgia impact.
population_specificity: 60 people diagnosed with fibromyalgia, randomly assigned to intervention or control groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the adjuvant effect of progressive muscle relaxation and interactive guided imagery (PMR-IGI) in alleviating pain and symptom distress in hospice patients with terminal cancer.
results_summary: PMR-IGI significantly reduced pain intensity and total symptom distress compared to usual care, with notable improvements in emotional symptoms like anxiety and depression. The intervention showed clinically meaningful effects, though further studies on repeated sessions were recommended.
population_specificity: Hospice patients with terminal cancer
study_duration: Single session with assessments 2 hours post-intervention and 24-hour follow-up

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of guided imagery on anxiety, depression, and vital signs in patients undergoing hemodialysis.
results_summary: Guided imagery significantly reduced anxiety and depression levels in the intervention group compared to the control group, along with statistically significant reductions in respiratory rate and heart rate.
population_specificity: 80 patients undergoing hemodialysis.

study_goal: To determine the effect of guided imagery as a non-pharmacological treatment for hypertension in pregnancy and its influence on perinatal outcomes.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to conclude that guided imagery effectively treats hypertension in pregnancy. Low-certainty evidence suggested little to no difference in antihypertensive drug use compared to quiet rest.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with hypertension (99 participants across two trials).
effective_dosage: One study: 15 minutes at least twice daily for four weeks or until delivery. Another study: guided imagery, self-monitoring, and biofeedback for four total hours, with twice-daily practice and three daily relaxation breaks.
study_duration: Four weeks or until delivery (whichever came first).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether guided imagery could reduce state and trait anxiety and improve sleep quality in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Guided imagery significantly reduced both state and trait anxiety and improved sleep quality in hemodialysis patients compared to routine care, with statistically significant differences observed post-intervention.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients at a teaching hospital in Kashan, Iran.
effective_dosage: Guided imagery six times a week via instructional CD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of EMDR and guided imagery on pain severity in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: Guided imagery significantly reduced pain in rheumatoid arthritis patients across physiological, affective, sensory-discriminative, and cognitive sub-scales, though EMDR showed greater pain reduction. Both interventions were more effective than the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether guided imagery is effective as a supplement to pharmaceutical pain management for postoperative orthopedic patients.
results_summary: The study concluded that guided imagery is recommended as an adjunct for pain management in orthopedic surgery patients, though more research is needed to determine optimal frequency and adherence.
population_specificity: Postoperative orthopedic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 12-week lifestyle intervention combining lifestyle education with guided imagery (stress reduction and lifestyle behavior components) on physical activity, dietary intake, and stress biomarkers in adolescents at risk for type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The abstract reports successful recruitment (97% of target population) but does not provide specific outcome results; future results will assess the intervention's effects on primary (physical activity, diet, stress biomarkers) and secondary (psychosocial, metabolic) outcomes.
population_specificity: Predominantly Latino adolescents recruited from four urban schools.
study_duration: 12-week intervention, followed by 6 months of maintenance and 6 months of no contact.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Guided Imagery on the comfort of oncology patients admitted to a palliative care unit.
results_summary: The study found that Guided Imagery significantly increased patient comfort and decreased heart rate, respiratory rate, and pain levels. The effects were statistically significant (P < .001) across all measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Oncology patients in a palliative care unit (n = 26).
effective_dosage: 2-session Guided Imagery program (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether guided imagery could reduce naturalistic food cravings, their intensity, and subsequent consumption.
results_summary: Guided imagery significantly reduced craving frequency, intensity, likelihood of consumption, and calorie intake, demonstrating effectiveness in managing everyday food cravings.
population_specificity: Participants experiencing naturalistic food cravings (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Three-minute audio clips per craving episode (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acceptability of a guided imagery therapy app for treating functional abdominal pain disorders in children and evaluate user preferences for its remote delivery.
results_summary: The study found favorable behavioral intention among mothers to use the app, with positive attitudes from both parents and children. Participants suggested improvements like visual components, background sounds, and session reminders to enhance compliance and therapeutic benefit.
population_specificity: Children aged 7-12 years with functional abdominal pain disorders and their mothers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of progressive muscle relaxation and guided imagery on stress, anxiety, and depression in pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in stress, anxiety, and depression scores in the relaxation group over three measurement times, while no significant changes were observed in the control group. The intervention was effective in improving mental health outcomes in pregnant women.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in Kashan at 28-36 weeks of gestation with mild-to-moderate stress, anxiety, and depression.
effective_dosage: Six sessions of progressive muscle relaxation and guided imagery (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document the scope of health outcomes and disease processes examined in guided imagery research, assess its efficacy, and identify barriers to clinical use.
results_summary: The study reviewed 320 RCTs involving 17,979 adults, finding benefits in pain coping, stroke recovery, anxiety, stress coping, and sport skills, but noted practitioner skepticism and time constraints as barriers.
population_specificity: Adult participants across diverse disciplines including psychology, sport sciences, rehabilitation, nursing, and medicine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effectiveness of combining progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) and guided imagery (GI) in alleviating psychological and adverse effects in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The combination of PMR and GI showed beneficial effects on mental state (mood, anxiety, depression) and toxicity (nausea, vomiting) in most trials, with some also reporting positive effects on biomarkers (heart rate, blood pressure, cortisol, immunity). However, the majority of trials focused solely on breast cancer patients, limiting generalizability.
population_specificity: Primarily breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy, with one trial including a mixed sample of breast and prostate cancer patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence on guided imagery combined with relaxation therapy for postoperative pain management.
results_summary: The study found that guided imagery, when combined with other complementary therapies, showed potential as a complementary approach to drug analgesia for postoperative pain control, though the quality of evidence was limited.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing postoperative pain management.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of guided imagery relaxation therapy on state anxiety and cortisol levels in patients undergoing video-laparoscopic bariatric surgery during the immediate preoperative period.
results_summary: The experimental group showed a statistically significant reduction in state anxiety scores (p = 0.005) and cortisol levels (p < 0.001) after the intervention compared to the control group. The study concluded that guided imagery relaxation therapy is effective for reducing preoperative anxiety and cortisol levels in this patient population.
population_specificity: Patients scheduled for video-laparoscopic bariatric surgery at a large teaching hospital in Minas Gerais, Brazil (n=24, 12 per group).
study_duration: Immediate preoperative period (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Healing Light Guided Imagery (HLGI) could improve depression, fatigue, and quality of life in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis compared to a wait-list control.
results_summary: HLGI significantly reduced depressed mood and fatigue while improving both physical and mental quality of life compared to the control group. The effects were statistically significant across all measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (N = 9 in HLGI group, N = 8 in control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of guided imagery for managing anxiety, pain, and insomnia in critically ill adult patients.
results_summary: The study found that guided imagery may help manage anxiety, pain, and insomnia in critical care, but the evidence is sparse, mixed, and weak, requiring further research with stronger designs and larger samples.
population_specificity: Critically ill adult patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a guided imagery-based multi-behavior intervention targeting psychological stress, food cravings, and physical activity in overweight and obese women.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in food cravings and increases in physical activity among participants using guided imagery compared to wait-list controls, with 89% compliance reported. The intervention was deemed acceptable for overweight and obese women.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese women (average age 45.5, average BMI 31.43).
effective_dosage: Daily practice of guided imagery for 35 consecutive days (specific script details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Gymnema sylvestre supplementation on glycemic control and lipid levels in patients with type-2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that Gymnema sylvestre significantly reduced fasting blood glucose, postprandial blood glucose, glycated hemoglobin, triglycerides, and total cholesterol in T2DM patients. The results suggest it may be an effective therapy for managing T2DM and associated complications.
population_specificity: Patients with type-2 diabetes mellitus (419 participants across 10 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review RCTs examining the effects of guided imagery on pain, function, anxiety, depression, and quality of life in adults with arthritis and other rheumatic diseases (AORD).
results_summary: All seven included studies reported statistically significant improvements in outcomes such as pain, function, anxiety, depression, and quality of life. Guided imagery was found to be beneficial for adults with AORD, with low or unclear risk of bias in most studies.
population_specificity: Adults with arthritis and other rheumatic diseases (AORD), average age 62.9 years.
effective_dosage: Guided imagery scripts delivered via audio technology (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Ranged from one-time exposure to 16 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate the α-glucosidase and α-amylase inhibitory activities of compounds isolated from Gymnema sylvestre.
results_summary: Five new pregnane glycosides and four known oleanane saponins were isolated from Gymnema sylvestre, with compounds 2-4 showing significant α-amylase inhibitory activity (IC50 values 113.0–176.2 µM).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (IC50 values provided in µM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the hepatoprotective and anti-hyperlipidemic effects of Gymnema Sylvestre leaves (GSL) hydro-methanolic extract, both alone and in combination with C. bonduc seed kernels, in alloxan-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: The study found that Gymnema Sylvestre leaves extract (GSLE) significantly reduced serum glucose, improved liver function markers, and lowered lipid profiles in diabetic rats, demonstrating hepatoprotective and hypolipidemic effects comparable to metformin. The combination of GSLE with CBSKE showed similar benefits.
population_specificity: Alloxan-induced diabetic albino Wistar rats (n=9 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the chemical profile of the Vietnamese Gymnema sylvestre variety and identify new oleanane triterpenoids using a biosynthesis-inspired approach.
results_summary: The study identified 119 oleanane triterpenoids, including 77 predicted new compounds, and constructed a multilayered chemical profile to analyze their logical relationships and biosynthetic pathways.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pharmacological and clinical potentials of Gymnema Sylvestre and its chemical constituents related to its therapeutic uses.
results_summary: The study found that Gymnema Sylvestre has blood glucose-lowering potential, along with anti-oxidant, antibiotic, anti-inflammatory, antiviral, gastro and hepatoprotective, anticancer, and lipid-lowering activities, attributed to phytochemicals like gurmarin, gymnemic acid, and gymnemasaponins.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of traditional and Ayurvedic uses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Gymnema sylvestre samples from Vietnam differ chemically and biologically from Indian samples and to identify potential anti-diabetic compounds.
results_summary: The study found that Vietnamese Gymnema sylvestre contains distinct compounds (gymnemosides ND1-ND9) not present in Indian samples, with three compounds (ND7-9) showing significant stimulatory effects on glucose uptake in adipocyte cells, suggesting anti-diabetic potential.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 adipocyte cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a cost-effective marker system for selecting high gymnemic acid-yielding accessions of Gymnema sylvestre by studying chromosomal anomalies in Brassica campestris root tips.
results_summary: The study found a direct correlation between the percentage of chromosomal fragmentation in Brassica campestris root tips and the percentage of gymnemic acid in treatment solutions, suggesting potential for a novel selection methodology for high-yielding Gymnema sylvestre accessions.
population_specificity: Brassica campestris (model organism)
effective_dosage: Different dilutions of gymnemagenin and 10% leaf extract of twenty Gymnema sylvestre accessions

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the hypolipidaemic activity of Gymnema Sylvestre (GS) leaves extract in rats with induced dyslipidaemia.
results_summary: GS at doses of 100mg/kg and 200mg/kg significantly improved lipid profiles by reducing TC, TG, VLDL, and LDL while increasing HDL, with the 200mg/kg dose being more effective. However, GS's effect was inferior to Atorvastatin.
population_specificity: Adult healthy female Wistar rats (150-200g) with induced dyslipidaemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacokinetic interaction between Gymnema Sylvestre extract and allopathic drugs (tolbutamide, amlodipine, phenacetin) in rats, focusing on CYP enzyme-mediated effects.
results_summary: The study found that Gymnema Sylvestre extract significantly inhibited CYP1A2 and CYP2C9 activity, altering the pharmacokinetics of phenacetin and tolbutamide but not amlodipine. The extract contained gymnemic acids, triterpenoids, and steroids, which likely contributed to these interactions.
population_specificity: Rats
interactions: Potential herb-drug interactions with drugs metabolized by CYP2C9 and CYP1A2 enzymes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Gymnema sylvestre on metabolic syndrome, insulin secretion, and insulin sensitivity in patients with MetS.
results_summary: Gymnema sylvestre administration led to significant decreases in body weight, BMI, and VLDL levels but did not affect MetS components, insulin secretion, or insulin sensitivity.
population_specificity: 24 patients aged 30-60 with diagnosed metabolic syndrome, not on pharmacological treatment.
effective_dosage: 300 mg capsules twice daily (600 mg total per day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the significance of Gymnema sylvestre in diabetes management, its herbal formulations, standardization, clinical trials on animal models, and its potential molecular target (PPARγ) for Gymnemic acid analogs.
results_summary: The study highlights Gymnema sylvestre's remarkable hypoglycemic properties and its role in diabetes therapeutics, suggesting PPARγ as a prospective molecular target for Gymnemic acid analogs to aid in developing natural product-based diabetes treatments.
population_specificity: Animal models (specific species not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish optimized culture conditions for hairy root production of Gymnema Sylvestre and confirm stable genetic integration for enhanced production of active compounds like gymnemic acid.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a protocol for hairy root cultures, confirmed stable T-DNA integration, and outlined extraction and analysis methods for gymnemic acid using HPTLC and HPLC.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore methods for enhancing the production of Gymnema biomass and gymnemic acid content through cell suspension cultures.
results_summary: The study described techniques for inducing callus and establishing cell suspension cultures to produce Gymnema biomass and analyze gymnemic acid using high-performance liquid chromatography. The abstract highlights Gymnema sylvestre's traditional uses and bioactive properties but does not present new efficacy data.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-based study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential neuroprotective effects of Gymnema sylvestre in a rat model of diabetic neuropathy, focusing on its impact on inflammation, oxidative stress, and nerve function.
results_summary: Gymnema sylvestre treatment improved pain thresholds, reduced proinflammatory cytokines, and ameliorated oxidative stress markers in diabetic rats. It also restored levels of growth factors (IGF, NGF) and corrected histopathological damage in sciatic nerve tissue.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a water-soluble fraction of Gymnema sylvestre ethanol extract on biochemical and molecular alterations in obese diabetic rats.
results_summary: The study found that Gymnema sylvestre significantly reduced heart rate, blood pressure, serum leptin, insulin, lipids, glucose, cardiac apoptosis markers, and visceral fat weight while improving antioxidant enzyme levels in obese diabetic rats.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese diabetic rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Gymnema sylvestre on glycemic control, insulin secretion, and insulin sensitivity in patients with impaired glucose tolerance (IGT).
results_summary: Gymnema sylvestre administration significantly reduced 2-h OGTT and A1C levels, improved insulin sensitivity (Matsuda index), and led to favorable changes in body weight, BMI, and LDL cholesterol. Nearly half of the patients achieved normal A1C values by the end of the intervention.
population_specificity: 30 patients with impaired glucose tolerance (IGT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the anti-stress, anti-allergic, and antiulcer activity of bioactive compounds in Gymnema sylvestre leaves.
results_summary: The study found that Gymnema sylvestre aqueous extracts exhibited significant antioxidant activity, anti-stress/anti-allergic effects, and gastric protection against aspirin-induced ulcers in mice. The purified fraction was identified as gymnemic acid, which demonstrated cytoprotective mechanisms.
population_specificity: Albino mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the phytochemistry and pharmacological activities of Gymnema Sylvestre, exploring its transition from traditional use to modern therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study found that Gymnema Sylvestre exhibits broad therapeutic effects, particularly in diabetes management by improving blood sugar homeostasis, reducing sugar cravings, and promoting pancreas regeneration. It also shows benefits for weight management, cholesterol reduction, and other conditions like arthritis and inflammation.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the preventative effects of Gymnema Sylvestre (GS) leaves extract against acetic acid-induced ulcerative colitis in Wistar rats, focusing on its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: GS pretreatment significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (TBARS), restored antioxidant levels (T-GSH, NP-SH, SOD, CAT), and lowered pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, TNF-α, IL-6), PGE2, and NO levels in colon tissues, demonstrating protective effects against ulcerative colitis. Histopathological findings further confirmed these benefits.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with experimentally induced ulcerative colitis.
effective_dosage: 50, 100, and 200 mg/kg/day of GS leaves extract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant activities of Gymnema Sylvestre and compare its phenolic and flavonoid contents, reducing power, and free radical scavenging activity against DPPH.
results_summary: Gymnema Sylvestre showed higher total phenolic content (53.63636 ± 0.454545 mg/g gallic acid equivalent) and exhibited moderate free radical scavenging activity against DPPH, suggesting significant antioxidant potential. The study concluded that its antioxidant compounds could be therapeutic candidates for oxidative stress-related diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of various extracts from Gymnema sylvestre on carbohydrate and lipid metabolism in animal and clinical studies.
results_summary: Gymnemic acid from Gymnema sylvestre demonstrated anti-obesity and antidiabetic properties, reducing body weight and inhibiting glucose absorption. Extracts also prevented triglyceride accumulation in muscle and liver and decreased fatty acid levels in circulation.
population_specificity: Animal and clinical studies (specific populations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the chemical and pharmacological reports on C-4 gem-dimethylated pentacyclic triterpenoids from Gymnema sylvestre, focusing on its medicinal properties.
results_summary: The study found that Gymnema sylvestre has beneficial effects for diabetes, digestion, anti-inflammatory, hypoglycemic, and anti-helmentic properties, along with potential uses for dyspepsia, constipation, jaundice, and other conditions. It also highlighted additional pharmacological activities such as anti-obesity, hypolipidemic, antimicrobial, and free radical scavenging properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (general medicinal plant research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-obesity effects of a water-soluble fraction of Gymnema sylvestre extract in a high-fat diet-induced obesity murine model.
results_summary: The water-soluble fraction of G. sylvestre significantly reduced serum lipids, leptin, insulin, glucose, apolipoprotein B, and LDH levels while increasing HDL-cholesterol, apolipoprotein A1, and antioxidant enzyme levels in liver tissue. Histopathological studies showed no pathological changes, indicating potential anti-obesity effects.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese rats (murine model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Gymnema Sylvestre's potential as a DPP-4 inhibitor and its effect on plasma active GLP-1 levels in diabetic rats.
results_summary: Gymnema Sylvestre showed moderate DPP-4 inhibition (IC50 773.22 µg/mL) and increased plasma active GLP-1 levels, peaking at 1.5 hours, though it was less potent than Pterocarpus marsupium and Eugenia jambolana.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats

study_goal: To determine the larvicidal activity of Gymnema sylvestre extracts against Culex tritaeniorynchus and identify the active principle in the most effective fraction.
results_summary: The study found that Gymnema sylvestre extracts exhibited significant larvicidal activity, with LC50 values ranging from 28.577 to 34.756 µg/ml across different solvents. The highest mortality rates were observed at 100 ppm.
population_specificity: Fourth instar larvae of Culex tritaeniorynchus (Japanese Encephalitis vector).
effective_dosage: Tested concentrations included 6.25 µg/ml and 100 ppm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Gymnema sylvestre extract (GSE) on high-fat diet-induced obesity and cardiac damage in Wistar rats.
results_summary: GSE significantly reversed obesity-related changes, including reduced body mass index, visceral fat, cardiac apoptosis, and improved lipid profiles and antioxidant enzyme levels in obese rats.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats (150-200 g body weight)

study_goal: To determine the larvicidal activity of Gymnema sylvestre extracts against Culex tritaeniorynchus and identify the active principle in the most effective fraction.
results_summary: Gymnema sylvestre extracts (acetone, chloroform, methanol) showed significant larvicidal activity, with 100 µg/mL causing the highest mortality. LC50 values ranged from 28.577 to 34.756 µg/mL, indicating strong efficacy.
population_specificity: Fourth instar larvae of Culex tritaeniorynchus (Japanese Encephalitis vector).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of G. sylvestre ethanol extract on gastric mucosal injury in rats, focusing on its protective mechanisms.
results_summary: G. sylvestre pretreatment provided dose-dependent protection against ethanol-induced gastric ulcers, reduced gastric secretions and acidity, and mitigated depletion of mucus, proteins, nucleic acids, and NP-SH levels, likely due to its free radical scavenging and cytoprotective properties.
population_specificity: Fasted rats with ethanol-induced gastric mucosal injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a novel high molecular weight Gymnema sylvestre extract (OSA®) on glucose tolerance in insulin-resistant mice and insulin secretion/synthesis in isolated mouse islets.
results_summary: OSA® improved glucose tolerance in ob/ob mice and increased insulin secretion at both substimulatory and stimulatory glucose concentrations in isolated mouse islets. Prolonged treatment also elevated preproinsulin mRNA expression and maintained total insulin content.
population_specificity: Insulin-resistant ob/ob mice and isolated mouse islets.
effective_dosage: 500 mg/kg (single dose in mice), 0.25 mg/ml (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of various metal salts on enhancing gymnemic acid production in Gymnema sylvestre suspension cultures.
results_summary: The study found that cadmium chloride (CdCl₂) at 2 mM concentration elicited the highest gymnemic acid production (59.97 mg/gDCW) after 24 hours, while silver nitrate (AgNO₃) showed the least response (18.35 mg/gDCW). Gymnemic acid accumulation depended on treatment time and elicitor concentration.
population_specificity: In vitro suspension cultures of Gymnema sylvestre.
effective_dosage: Metal salts at concentrations ranging from 1-2 mM.
study_duration: 12-16 days (maximum gymnemic acid production on day 12, maximum biomass on day 16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiobesity effects of a saponin-rich fraction of Gymnema sylvestre (SGE) in diet-induced obese rats.
results_summary: SGE significantly reduced body weight, food consumption, visceral organ weight, and improved lipid and glucose profiles in obese rats, while showing no significant effects in normal diet rats. It also inhibited pancreatic lipase activity in vitro.
population_specificity: Cafeteria and high-fat diet-induced obese rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of drug-induced liver injury (DILI) associated with Gymnema Sylvestre use in a diabetic patient and review possible mechanisms.
results_summary: The study reports a case of DILI linked to Gymnema Sylvestre in a diabetic patient, noting no prior reports of liver injury associated with the herb. The authors suggest possible mechanisms but provide no broader efficacy data.
population_specificity: A diabetic patient using Gymnema Sylvestre.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a novel Gymnema sylvestre extract (OSA(R)) on insulin secretion and blood glucose levels in patients with Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: OSA(R) administration significantly increased circulating insulin and C-peptide levels while reducing fasting and post-prandial blood glucose. In vitro experiments confirmed OSA(R) directly stimulated insulin secretion from human ß-cells.
population_specificity: Small cohort of patients with T2DM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate and identify an antidiabetic compound from Gymnema sylvestre and evaluate its effects on biochemical parameters in diabetic rats.
results_summary: Dihydroxy gymnemic triacetate at 20mg/kg significantly improved plasma glucose, insulin, HbA1c, tissue glycogen, lipid parameters, and hepatic enzyme activities in diabetic rats compared to controls. The compound demonstrated hypoglycemic and hypolipidemic effects.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a novel Gymnema Sylvestre extract (OSA) on insulin secretion in MIN6 beta-cells and human islets, and assess its potential as a therapy for Type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Low concentrations of OSA stimulated insulin secretion in MIN6 cells and human islets via Ca2+ influx without harming cell viability, while higher concentrations caused cell damage. The effects were partially dependent on extracellular Ca2+.
population_specificity: MIN6 beta-cell line and isolated human islets of Langerhans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hypoglycemic activity of Gymnema sylvestre leaf water extract in normal and alloxan-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: The extract significantly reduced blood glucose levels in both normal and diabetic rats and normalized altered levels of urea, uric acid, and creatinine in diabetic rats. Protein levels, which were decreased in diabetic rats, were also affected by the treatment.
population_specificity: Normal and alloxan-induced diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence supporting the use of Gymnema sylvestre as a potential treatment for diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings but indicates a systematic review was conducted to discuss the best available evidence on Gymnema sylvestre's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate how Gymnema Sylvestre impairs sweet taste perception and illustrate gustatory sensation principles in an educational setting.
results_summary: Gymnema Sylvestre profoundly impaired sweet sensation, altering the perception of sweetness in sugar, chocolate, and candy without affecting other primary tastes. The herb's effect was intense and memorable, enhancing students' understanding of gustatory sensation.
population_specificity: Undergraduate neuroscience students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to extract and quantify gymnemic acid from callus cultures of Gymnema sylvestre for potential use in diabetes and obesity treatment.
results_summary: The study successfully extracted gymnemic acid through gymnemagenin from callus cultures, achieving 98.9% recovery with high linearity in the 2-10 microgram range. The method demonstrated reliable separation and quantification using densitometric scanning.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro callus cultures)

study_goal: The researchers reviewed the chemistry and pharmacology of Gymnema Sylvestre, focusing on its traditional uses and potential therapeutic effects.
results_summary: Gymnema Sylvestre modulates taste, particularly suppressing sweet sensations, and is used for diabetes mellitus, obesity, and caries. Anti-allergic, antiviral, and lipid-lowering effects are also reported. Efforts have been made to mask its bitter taste.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Gymnema sylvestre extracts could have therapeutic potential for non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM) by examining their effects on insulin secretion from pancreatic beta-cells and islets.
results_summary: GS4 stimulated insulin release from beta-cells and islets but increased cell permeability, as indicated by trypan blue uptake, suggesting it does not act via regulated exocytosis pathways. The study confirmed G. sylvestre's stimulatory effects on insulin secretion but raised concerns about cell integrity.
population_specificity: Rat islets of Langerhans and pancreatic beta-cell lines (HIT-T15, MIN6, RINm5F).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Gymnema sylvestre could improve insulin resistance in streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: The study found that Gymnema sylvestre (120 mg/kg/day) did not improve insulin resistance in diabetic rats, unlike Seishin-renshi-in, which showed positive effects.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the production and accumulation of gymnemic acid in Gymnema sylvestre under different stress conditions and light treatments.
results_summary: The study found that gymnemic acid production was significantly higher in callus treated with 2,4-D and kinetin, with blue light increasing accumulation up to 4.4-fold compared to fluorescent light. The compound was isolated using preparative TLC and validated by HPTLC and HPLC methods.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro callus culture study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Gymnema Sylvestre could regulate blood sugar levels and correct metabolic derangements in diabetic rabbits.
results_summary: Gymnema Sylvestre administration regulated blood glucose levels, improved glucose utilization via insulin-dependent pathways, and reversed pathological liver changes in diabetic rabbits. It also increased glucose uptake and incorporation into glycogen and protein in the liver, kidney, and muscle.
population_specificity: Alloxan diabetic rabbits
effective_dosage: Dried leaf powder (specific dosage not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of Gymnema sylvestre in managing type 2 diabetes by assessing its impact on blood glucose, lipid profiles, and other clinico-biochemical markers.
results_summary: Supplementation with Gymnema sylvestre reduced polyphagia, fatigue, fasting and post-prandial blood glucose, glycated hemoglobin, and improved lipid profiles, suggesting beneficial effects in diabetes management.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetics from a free-living population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute and chronic effects of Gymnema Sylvestre (GS4) on glucose homeostasis in non-diabetic and mildly diabetic rats.
results_summary: GS4 significantly reduced serum glucose response in non-diabetic rats and improved glucose tolerance in mildly diabetic rats, though insulin response was unaffected. Chronic administration showed a tendency to lower fed-state glucose levels without altering body weight, food intake, or pancreatic markers.
population_specificity: Non-diabetic and streptozocin-induced mildly diabetic rats.
effective_dosage: 1 g/kg body weight (acute study); diet supplemented with GS4 (chronic study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the implementation of the end-user-targeted I-PROTECT injury prevention program in youth handball teams and clubs.
results_summary: The study evaluates the implementation of the I-PROTECT program, which includes targeted information and injury prevention training via a mobile app, compared to existing injury prevention programs. Outcomes will be assessed using the Reach, Effectiveness, Adoption, Implementation, and Maintenance framework.
population_specificity: Youth handball players (female and male), coaches, club administrators, and parents/guardians in Sweden.
study_duration: Duration of the handball season (exact length not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of concentric fatigue on proprioception, motor control, and upper limb performance in handball players.
results_summary: Concentric fatigue led to significant deficits in joint position awareness, kinesthesia, motor control, and upper extremity performance, with notable declines in YBT-UQ and ASH test results, though reflex reaction time was only marginally affected.
population_specificity: 46 right-handed male handball players (age 26.1 ± 5.54 years).
effective_dosage: Fatigue protocol involved 30 repetitions of maximal effort isokinetic contractions at 900°/sec for shoulder external and internal rotator muscles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between shoulder and trunk stability and throwing velocity and accuracy in elite female handball players.
results_summary: The study found significant relationships between medial shoulder stability and throwing accuracy, with the intervention group showing notable improvements in trunk stability, shoulder stability, throwing velocity, and accuracy compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 151 elite female handball players from the Hungarian first league (9 teams).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of proprioceptive exercises on postural control in handball players with chronic ankle instability.
results_summary: Both groups improved their functional ankle instability scores and reduced ankle sprains, with the experimental group showing greater improvements in postural control measures. Proprioceptive exercises positively impacted postural control, particularly in the experimental group.
population_specificity: Handball players with chronic ankle instability (n = 22, divided into experimental and control groups).
effective_dosage: Proprioceptive exercises performed three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of injuries and illnesses in adolescent Danish handball players, evaluate injury incidence rates and burden, and examine initial injury management strategies.
results_summary: Nearly half of the players reported past-year shoulder, knee, or ankle injuries, with a weekly injury prevalence of 21% and illness prevalence of 2%. Females had the highest injury burden from knee injuries, while males had the highest burden from shoulder injuries, and players frequently managed injuries independently, including using home-sourced analgesics.
population_specificity: 679 highest-division Danish handball players aged 14-18.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of Fascial Manipulation® on the range of motion (ROM) of internal rotation and horizontal adduction in asymptomatic handball players, as these are risk factors for shoulder injuries.
results_summary: The study found that a single session of Fascial Manipulation® significantly improved glenohumeral internal rotation and horizontal adduction ROM immediately and one month post-treatment, with reduced subjective tightness/stiffness compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic handball players.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of different exercise training interventions on physical fitness and technical skills in handball players.
results_summary: Exercise training significantly improved speed and agility in handball players, but evidence for muscular strength, shooting ability, and dribbling skills was limited. No evidence was found for impacts on power, endurance, flexibility, body composition, cardiovascular fitness, or cardiorespiratory fitness.
population_specificity: Handball players

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of arthroscopic excision for treating symptomatic complete suprapatellar plica syndrome in a young athlete.
results_summary: The study found that arthroscopic excision of the plica resulted in complete resolution of symptoms and allowed the patient to return to sports activity. It also noted that conservative measures should be tried first, with surgery reserved for cases where conservative therapy fails.
population_specificity: 19-year-old female patient with complete suprapatellar plica syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of movement-based (unspecific) versus game-based (sport-specific) flywheel resistance training on performance in highly trained youth handball players.
results_summary: Both training groups improved change-of-direction performance, but the game-based group showed greater improvements. Handball throwing speed remained unchanged regardless of training condition.
population_specificity: Highly trained youth male handball players (n=25).
effective_dosage: Two sessions per week of flywheel resistance training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether GS4, a water-soluble extract of Gymnema sylvestre, could reduce insulin requirements and improve glycemic and lipid control in patients with insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM).
results_summary: GS4 therapy reduced insulin requirements, fasting blood glucose, and glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) and plasma protein levels, while serum lipids returned to near-normal levels. However, HbA1c and glycosylated plasma protein levels remained higher than controls, and no significant improvements were observed in the insulin-only control group after 10-12 months.
population_specificity: 27 patients with insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) on insulin therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute effects of a systemic acupuncture protocol on strength and power performance in male handball players.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in vertical jump performance between groups. However, a significant reduction in maximal isometric voluntary contraction (MIVC) was observed in the Sham group, and both Sham and acupuncture groups showed a significant reduction in handgrip strength.
population_specificity: 27 male handball players divided into three groups (Sham, Acupuncture, Control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Gymnema Sylvestre extracts (GS3 and GS4) on blood glucose homeostasis and pancreatic endocrine tissue in streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: Both GS3 and GS4 extracts normalized fasting blood glucose levels (GS3 after 60 days, GS4 after 20 days), increased serum insulin levels, and doubled islet and beta cell numbers in diabetic rats. The therapy appeared to restore blood glucose homeostasis through pancreatic repair/regeneration.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-treated diabetic rats.
study_duration: 60 days for GS3, 20 days for GS4.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two 10-week elastic band training programs (standard vs. contrast) on athletic performance in adolescent female handball players.
results_summary: Both training programs improved sprint, change-of-direction, strength, and force-velocity performance compared to the control group, with contrast elastic band training showing superior gains in upper-limb strength and force-velocity characteristics.
population_specificity: Adolescent female handball players (aged 16.0 ± 0.5 years).
effective_dosage: Twice a week supplementing regular training.

study_goal: To compare kinetic chain components in overhead athletes (volleyball and handball) with and without shoulder pain.
results_summary: Athletes with shoulder pain exhibited reduced hip internal rotation range of motion, lower trunk endurance, and decreased neuromuscular control in the Y balance test compared to those without pain.
population_specificity: Forty-one volleyball and handball athletes (21 with shoulder pain, 20 without).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess zinc (Zn) status in professional handball players during the competitive period and determine the effect of Zn supplementation.
results_summary: Plasma Zn levels were higher in handball players after Zn intervention, and differences in the gene expression of Zn transporters were observed, with several transporters being up-regulated after 8 weeks.
population_specificity: Ten male professional handball players (ATH-G) and twelve controls (CG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the level of evidence for the effect of resistance training (RT) on throwing performance (velocity and accuracy) in handball players.
results_summary: The study found strong evidence for the effectiveness of RT using barbells in increasing throwing velocity, particularly for running throws, jumping throws, and standing throws. Other RT modalities (elastic bands, medicine balls, core training, ballistic training) showed no significant benefits due to limited studies and high heterogeneity.
population_specificity: 727 handball players (388 males, 292 females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a 10-week contrast rubber band training program on athletic performance in young female handball players.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly greater improvements in agility, vertical jump, strength, force-velocity scores, and repeated sprint times compared to the control group.
