The study concluded that contrast rubber band training effectively enhances most motor abilities in youth female handball athletes.
population_specificity: Young female handball players (15.8 ± 0.2 years).
effective_dosage: 20 sessions over two weeks (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a holistic injury prevention intervention for youth handball by co-creating it with end-users and applying behavior change and implementation theories.
results_summary: The intervention included targeted information and training available via a mobile app, with modules for players, coaches, and administrators, integrating physical and psychological injury prevention strategies. Initial feedback from early end-users was generally positive.
population_specificity: Youth handball players, coaches, club administrators, and caregivers.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of 6-week eccentric isokinetic resistance training on strength, flexibility, and fiber architecture characteristics of the external rotators in junior male handball players compared to conventional preventive training.
results_summary: The eccentric training group showed significant improvements in eccentric strength (+15%), fascicle length (+13% and +8% in supraspinatus and infraspinatus), and fractional anisotropy (+9% and +6%), but no change in range of motion. The control group did not show these improvements.
population_specificity: Junior male handball players

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a 6-week combined plyometric and sprint-training program on sand versus regular preseason training on athletic performance and technical actions in beach handball players.
results_summary: The experimental group (plyometric + sprint + BH training) showed significant improvements in all athletic performance measures, including jumps, sprint, and specific throwing speeds, while the control group (BH training only) only improved in endurance performance. Significant time-group differences favored the experimental group in squat jump, countermovement jump, Abalakov jump, jump throw velocity, and 360º jump throw velocity.
population_specificity: Beach handball players (n=24, split into control and experimental groups of 12 each).
effective_dosage: Not specified (training program details not quantified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of three learning approaches (contextual interference, differential learning, and free-play control) on the parallel learning of handball, volleyball, and basketball skills, considering participants' prior sport backgrounds.
results_summary: The differential learning (DL) group showed significant short-term and long-term improvements in non-mastered handball and basketball skills, with trends in mastered volleyball skills, outperforming the contextual interference and control groups.
population_specificity: 45 male athletes (15 handball, 15 volleyball, and 15 basketball players) aged 22 ± 1.4 years with at least 6 years of experience in their primary sport.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of the Paleo diet (PD) on body composition and blood markers (carbohydrates, lipids, insulin, irisin, adiponectin, and leptin) in handball players.
results_summary: The PD group showed lower body mass and higher adiponectin levels but no significant changes in body composition or other blood markers compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 25 handball players (14 in the PD group, 11 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary composition: 35% carbohydrates, 35% fats, 30% protein).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of exercise-based injury-prevention programs in reducing sports injuries among team handball players.
results_summary: The study found that injury-prevention programs significantly reduced the risk of shoulder, lower extremity, knee, ankle, and anterior cruciate ligament injuries in team handball players, with odds ratios ranging from 0.53 to 0.66.
population_specificity: Competitive team handball players

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes of the Latarjet-Patte (LP) procedure in treating shoulder instability in professional handball players.
results_summary: The LP procedure showed high success rates, with 85% of players returning to sport (RTS), 80% returning at the same level, and 73% experiencing no throwing pain. However, persistent symptoms were noted in older players, backcourt players, and those with large Hill-Sachs lesions.
population_specificity: 18 professional handball players (17 male, 1 female; mean age 22.9 years) with shoulder instability.
study_duration: Mean follow-up period of 6.6 years (minimum 2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two 8-week in-season strength-training programs (plyometric vs. eccentric-overload) on physical and technical parameters in male handball players.
results_summary: Both plyometric and eccentric-overload training improved counter movement jump, Abalakov vertical jump, and handball-throwing speed compared to regular training, but did not affect sprint time, cardiorespiratory endurance, or post-exercise heart rate and blood lactate.
population_specificity: 36 male handball players.
effective_dosage: Three times per week for plyometric or eccentric-overload exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of continuous endurance training versus handball small-sided games (SSGs) in improving fitness outcomes for female handball players during the preseason.
results_summary: The SSG group showed significant improvements in agility (T test), ball-throwing velocity, and intermittent endurance (Yo-Yo IR1), while the running group improved in standing long-jump, ball-throwing velocity, and Yo-Yo IR1. SSGs were deemed more suitable due to exercise specificity.
population_specificity: Eighteen female handball players from a first league in the Czech Republic, divided into two groups (SSG and running).
effective_dosage: SSG group: two small-sided games per week; running group: two continuous endurance sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the effectiveness of pulsed radiofrequency (pRF) in treating superficial peroneal nerve (SPN) entrapment in a handball athlete, avoiding invasive surgical options and enabling early return to play.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasound-guided nerve block and hydrodissection provided major symptom improvement for three weeks, followed by successful long-term pain resolution and full sports participation after pRF treatment, with no complications over 24 months of follow-up.
population_specificity: A 34-year-old handball athlete with SPN entrapment-related neuropathic pain.
effective_dosage: 2ml of 2% lidocaine and 3ml of 0.2% ropivacaine for diagnostic nerve block.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of different weekly exercise volumes (1, 2, or 3 sessions of 60-minute recreational team handball) on bone health, body composition, and physical fitness in inactive middle-to-older-aged males over 16 weeks.
results_summary: Recreational team handball improved bone health, body composition, and physical fitness, with greater benefits observed in groups performing 2 or 3 weekly sessions. Training intensity was similar across groups, suggesting volume was the key factor for health improvements, and participants reported high fun levels, indicating potential for long-term adherence.
population_specificity: Inactive middle-to-older-aged males (68 ± 4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a progressive, individualized sport-specific training program combined with communication and coordination in reducing injury prevalence among youth female and male handball and football players transitioning to a sports academy high school.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significantly lower average weekly injury prevalence (11%) compared to the control group (19%), with a 1.8 times higher injury risk in the control group during the first 12 weeks. The program effectively reduced all-complaint injuries, particularly during unsupervised periods like summer holidays.
population_specificity: 42 Norwegian youth athletes (male and female) transitioning to a sports academy high school, aged 15.4–15.5 years.
effective_dosage: Weekly progressive, individualized sport-specific training programs and weekly follow-up telephone calls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of teacher versus peer verbal encouragement on offensive and defensive performance indicators in handball small-sided games.
results_summary: Peer verbal encouragement showed significant positive effects on balls played and shots on goal compared to teacher encouragement, with no significant differences favoring teacher encouragement in any performance indicators.
population_specificity: 14 untrained male secondary school students aged 17-18.
study_duration: Three sessions, each involving one 8-minute period per encouragement type.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the dose-response effects of recreational team handball (TH) on cardiometabolic health and physical fitness in inactive middle-aged-to-elderly men without TH experience.
results_summary: The study found that recreational TH improved aerobic performance and cardiometabolic health, with the greatest benefits observed in the group performing three weekly sessions. Positive effects included increased VO2peak, reduced body and fat mass, and improved fasting plasma insulin levels.
population_specificity: Inactive middle-aged-to-elderly men (67.5 ± 4.2 years) without TH experience.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effects of recreational team handball training on global health status in inactive postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that recreational team handball training improved cardiovascular, bone, metabolic health, body composition, and physical fitness markers in postmenopausal women, with sustained and additional benefits observed over 36 weeks.
population_specificity: Inactive postmenopausal women (n=45; age 65±6 years).
study_duration: 36 weeks (16 weeks initial, followed by 20 weeks extension).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the subjective external load (eTL) of handball learning tasks and analyze differences based on game situation and space.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in subjective eTL depending on game situation and space, with small-sided games and full games in medium or large spaces showing higher physiological and motor demands. Planning and organizing tasks with attacking/defending players and appropriate game space were highlighted as important.
population_specificity: In-service teachers (five men and two women) with over 10 years of teaching practice, analyzing 306 learning tasks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of personalized dietary plans on psychological factors in young professional female handball players with low energy availability.
results_summary: The study found that dietary plans (free diet, Mediterranean diet, high antioxidant diet) improved mood and body perception over time but showed no significant differences between the diets. Eating behavior improved slightly but not statistically significantly.
population_specificity: 21 young professional female handball players (aged 22 ± 4 years, 172.0 ± 5.4 cm, 68.4 ± 6.7 kg) with low energy availability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-movement speed training versus high-movement speed training on maximal bench press strength, throwing velocity, and skeletal muscle mass in handball players.
results_summary: Both training groups showed significant improvements in skeletal muscle mass, bench press strength, and throwing velocity after five weeks, with no statistically significant differences between the two training approaches.
population_specificity: 22 university handball players
effective_dosage: Group 1: 0.75-0.96 m/s bar speed (~60% 1RM); Group 2: 1.03-1.20 m/s bar speed (~40% 1RM); both groups trained three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 6-week core strengthening training program integrated into regular handball training improved physical and athletic performance compared to regular handball training alone.
results_summary: The study found that core strengthening improved muscular endurance and shoulder mobility/stability but did not enhance handball-specific performance (e.g., throwing velocity). Significant improvements were observed in the Bourban test and YBT-UQ for the intervention group.
population_specificity: Male sub-elite adolescent handball players (age 16.9 ± 0.6 and 17.2 ± 0.8 years).
effective_dosage: "Big 3" core exercises (cross curls-up, side bridge, quadrupedal stance) triweekly for 20-30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acute effects of handball-specific loading on the acromiohumeral distance (AHD) in experienced handball players and non-handball athletes, and to identify potential risk factors related to shoulder health.
results_summary: Handball-specific loading significantly reduced AHD in both groups, particularly at 60° abduction, with experienced players showing greater reductions. Poor shoulder strength exacerbated AHD reduction, suggesting a need for targeted strengthening exercises to mitigate injury risk.
population_specificity: 20 experienced handball players (10 male, 10 female) and 20 non-handball athletes (10 male, 10 female), aged 24 ± 5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of eight weeks of inspiratory muscle training (IMT) using the POWERBreathe device on spirometric variables, VO2max, and perception of exertion in women's handball players.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvements in spirometric variables or VO2max in the experimental group, though there was a trend toward maintaining or increasing values compared to the control group, which showed a decline. IMT did not improve perception of exertion at submaximal intensity.
population_specificity: Twenty-four women's handball players (13 in the experimental group, 11 in the control group).

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of dry cupping therapy (DCT) and creatine supplementation (CS) on cardiovascular and inflammatory responses to the Wingate test in handball players.
results_summary: Heart-rate means were lower in DCT, CS, and CS+DCT conditions compared to control. The study suggests potential benefits of these interventions for mitigating exercise-induced stress, but full results (e.g., inflammatory markers) are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 12 male young handball players.
effective_dosage: 60 g of creatine per day (20 g per meal, 3 meals/day) for 3 consecutive days.
study_duration: 3 days (creatine supplementation); DCT applied post-Wingate test (single session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of six-week eccentric hamstring training on dynamic balance performance in youth handball players of different maturity statuses (pre- or post-peak height velocity).
results_summary: The study found that somatic maturation influences dynamic balance performance, with post-PHV players showing greater improvement after eccentric hamstring training compared to pre-PHV players. The intervention significantly improved balance scores, particularly in the post-PHV group.
population_specificity: 45 young male handball players (14.6 ± 0.3 years) from a local national handball club, divided into pre-PHV and post-PHV groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an injury prevention program could effectively reduce overuse shoulder injuries in handball athletes.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the prevalence of overuse shoulder injuries between the intervention and control groups, nor did compliance with the program affect outcomes. The intervention also did not significantly reduce symptom intensity measured by the WOSI.
population_specificity: Men's and women's handball teams (u-19 and senior athletes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the surgical management of a latissimus dorsi tear in a professional female handball player and assess recovery outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that surgical treatment of a 3cm latissimus dorsi tear in the dominant arm led to progressive improvement, with the patient returning to sport at 12 weeks and achieving excellent UCLA and DASH scores by 6 months.
population_specificity: Professional female handball player with an acute latissimus dorsi tear.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of an 8-week handball warm-up program (HWP) on dynamic balance among elite adolescent handball players.
results_summary: The HWP significantly improved dynamic balance, as measured by the Biodex Balance System and Y Balance test, for both dominant and non-dominant legs, with improvements ranging from 7.9% to 44.6% across stability indexes. The trained group showed greater improvements compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Elite adolescent handball players (n=24)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) combined with plyometric exercise on the physical fitness of junior male handball players.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in sprint performance, change of direction, jump performance, repeated sprint ability, and aerobic capacity in the intervention group compared to the control group. Effect sizes ranged from small to large, with the most notable improvements in repeated sprint performance (d=0.83) and sprint times (d=0.33-0.58).
population_specificity: Junior male handball players (~17 years old).
effective_dosage: Not specified (HIIT and plyometric exercises replaced part of their regular training regimen).

study_goal: To determine the effects of dry needling in active myofascial trigger points in the teres major muscle on pain, shoulder range of motion, strength, and tissue extensibility in professional handball athletes.
results_summary: Dry needling significantly improved pain intensity during throwing actions, internal rotation range of motion, and tissue extensibility compared to the control group, with large effect sizes. No significant improvement was found for isometric strength.
population_specificity: Professional handball athletes with shoulder pain (n=30).
effective_dosage: Single session of ultrasound-guided dry needling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of an eight-week self-regulated resistance training program on repeated shuttle sprint and jump ability in female college handball players.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in jump height (from 1836.4 W to 2088.9 W) and running speed (from 3.2 m/s to 4.0 m/s) after the training program, along with reduced power and speed loss between test sets.
population_specificity: 16 female handball players from a Chilean university's physics and mathematics faculty.
effective_dosage: Not specified (loads controlled by self-perceived effort using OMNI-RES scale).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding a 9-week elastic resistance band training to regular handball sessions improves strength endurance, maximal isometric strength, and throwing velocity compared to regular training alone.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in strength endurance (CKCUEST) and throwing velocity, with a trend toward improved maximal isometric strength in the non-throwing arm's internal rotators, compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 32 handball players (16 intervention, 16 control) aged 16.9–17.0 years.
effective_dosage: Elastic resistance band exercises 3 times per week for 20–30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if sling-based rotational training improved shooting performance in female handball players and whether changes were linked to core strength and rotational velocity.
results_summary: Sling-based training increased ball velocity by 3.2% across shooting techniques, while the control group saw a 3% decrease. Both groups showed improved rotational velocity but no change in core strength.
population_specificity: 25 female outfield handball players (mean age 19.5 ± 2.0 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare hamstring activation patterns (specifically medial semitendinosus vs. biceps femoris) during unilateral vs. bilateral lower limb exercises to identify optimal exercises for ACL injury prevention in female handball players.
results_summary: Bilateral hip thrust showed the highest overall hamstring activation, while kettlebell swing and Romanian deadlift preferentially activated the medial semitendinosus over the biceps femoris, suggesting these exercises may be superior for ACL injury prevention. Kinematic analysis revealed correlations between knee joint angle and semitendinosus activation.
population_specificity: 23 female elite team handball players

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate postoperative outcomes, including return-to-sport rates, of arthroscopic treatment for anterior shoulder instability in professional handball players.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in Rowe and ASES scores post-surgery, with an 83% return-to-sport rate and 64% returning to preinjury levels. Younger players (<20 years) had significantly lower return-to-sport rates compared to older players (≥20 years).
population_specificity: 44 competitive handball players (47 shoulders) with anterior shoulder instability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors and diseases in asymptomatic Hungarian elite handball referees through extended cardiac screening.
results_summary: The study found a high percentage of elite Hungarian handball referees had cardiovascular risk factors or diseases, including dyslipidaemia (41%), elevated resting blood pressure (38%), and echocardiography/CMR abnormalities (19%). Lifestyle changes or medical interventions were recommended for many referees.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic Hungarian elite handball referees (n=100, age 29.6±7.9 years, 64 male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a short shoulder external rotation (ER) strength program using elastic bands improved ER strength and the ER/IR strength ratio in adolescent handball players.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in ER strength or the ER/IR ratio in the intervention group compared to the control group, with minimal between-group differences.
population_specificity: Adolescent handball players (92 participants, mean age 16.6 years, 3 female and 3 male teams).
effective_dosage: 2 exercises performed 3 times per week after handball training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 4-week multidirectional running sprint training intervention on agility and speed in male and female handball players.
results_summary: Male players showed improvements in 505 Preferred Side, 505 Non-Preferred Side, and 10 m sprint, while female players improved in T-test, 505 Preferred Side, 505 Non-Preferred Side, and 10 m sprint. No significant improvements were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: 31 handball players (15 male, 16 female)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a functional high-load exercise intervention could prevent patellar tendon pain in adolescent male handball players by addressing muscle-tendon imbalances.
results_summary: The experimental group, which incorporated functional high-load exercises, showed no cases of clinically significant tendon pain aggravation, while 30% of the control group did. Both groups exhibited similar strength and muscle thickness improvements, but tendon stiffness and strain remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Adolescent male handball players aged 12-14 years.
effective_dosage: Two sessions per week with functional high-load exercises (≥3s loading duration per repetition).
study_duration: Over a season (specific duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a recreational team handball exercise program on bone health, postural balance, and body composition in inactive postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that short-term recreational team handball improved lumbar spine bone mineral density (+1.5%) and content (+2.3%), increased bone formation markers (P1NP +37.6%, OC +41.9%), and enhanced postural balance (-7% falls), with no changes in the control group.
population_specificity: Inactive postmenopausal women (68.3 ± 6.2 years) without prior handball experience.
effective_dosage: Two to three 60-minute training sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of bi-weekly lower limb elastic band-based loaded plyometric training on physical performance in junior handball players during the in-season.
results_summary: The study found that the experimental group showed significant improvements in absolute and relative muscle power, sprint times (5m and 30m), change of direction (COD) times, and repeated COD performance compared to controls. Both groups showed improvements in some anthropometric parameters, 1-RM half-back squat, and vertical jump performance.
population_specificity: Junior male handball players (age ~17-18 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how genetic variations in CYP1A2 and ADORA2A influence the ergogenic response to acute caffeine intake in professional handball players.
results_summary: Caffeine improved countermovement jump height, sprint velocity, and ball throwing velocity in professional handball players, but the ergogenic response was not significantly modulated by CYP1A2 or ADORA2A genotypes, except for a minor effect on 7m ball throwing.
population_specificity: Thirty-one professional handball players (16 men, 15 women) with low daily caffeine consumption (60 ± 25 mg·d-1).
effective_dosage: 3 mg·kg-1·body mass, ingested 60 min before testing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation of shoulder injuries in handball players, distinguishing between sports-specific adaptation and pathological conditions.
results_summary: The study found that handball-related shoulder injuries often result from abrupt disruptions during play, leading to overstrain reactions in tissues. MRI is the preferred diagnostic tool, and treatment involves sports breaks, pain management, physiotherapy, or surgery if necessary, with most patients returning to sports post-rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Handball players, particularly those with shoulder injuries or complaints.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of recreational team handball on aerobic performance, cardiorespiratory fitness, and cardiometabolic health in untrained postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that recreational team handball significantly improved aerobic exercise performance (70% increase in YYIE1 performance), VO2peak (7% increase), and some cardiometabolic markers (e.g., reduced total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol) in postmenopausal women. No significant improvements were observed in the control group except for a minor increase in treadmill test time to exhaustion.
population_specificity: Untrained postmenopausal women (age 68 ± 6 years) with no prior team handball experience.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze injury patterns, risks, and prevention strategies in handball athletes.
results_summary: The study found that handball has a high injury rate, with over half of injuries allowing continued play after treatment, while the rest result in lost training/match time. Injuries are often contact-related but not due to foul play, highlighting potential for prevention, particularly for knee and shoulder injuries.
population_specificity: Handball athletes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of 12-week chokeberry extract supplementation on redox status, body composition, lipid profile, and biochemical parameters in active handball players.
results_summary: The study found that chokeberry extract reduced prooxidants, increased catalase activity, decreased body fat, improved lipid profile (higher HDL), and enhanced hemoglobin and red blood cell counts while reducing leukocytes.
population_specificity: 16 active handball players aged 16-24 years.
effective_dosage: 30 mL of liquid chokeberry extract daily before training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in gene expression in elite handball athletes before, after, and in the absence of an 8-week multivitamin/mineral supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that elite handball athletes exhibited different gene regulation profiles related to sports performance compared to sedentary controls, with the nutritional intervention promoting gene upregulation. Specific genes involved in metabolism, inflammation, and muscle function were modulated, showing moderate to large effect sizes.
population_specificity: Thirteen elite handball athletes (aged 22.9 ± 2.7 years) and 13 sedentary controls (aged 20.9 ± 2.8 years).
study_duration: 8 weeks of supplementation, followed by 8 weeks without supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 7 weeks of plyometric training on stable surfaces versus sand on performance measures in junior male handball players.
results_summary: Plyometric training on sand (PS) improved sprint speed, change of direction, vertical jump performance, repeated sprint ability, and dynamic/static balance more effectively than training on a stable surface (P) or the control group (C). Both plyometric groups showed significant improvements in jump performance and balance compared to the control.
population_specificity: Junior male handball players (n=31, divided into three groups: C=10, PS=11, P=10).
effective_dosage: Not specified (plyometric training regimen details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of the Oslo Sports Trauma Research Center shoulder injury prevention program on external rotation strength and internal rotation range of motion in youth handball players.
results_summary: The intervention program did not significantly affect external rotation strength or internal rotation range of motion compared to the control group, suggesting its preventive effects may be due to other factors. Both groups showed minor improvements in external rotation strength, but no changes in internal rotation range of motion were observed.
population_specificity: Youth handball players (57 participants, mean age 17.1 years, three female teams, one male team).
effective_dosage: Three times per week as part of handball warm-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in kidney parameters and hydration status in female handball players during intensive training and tapering phases before a competition.
results_summary: Intensive training increased glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) and fractional sodium excretion (FeNa), while tapering preserved eGFR benefits but reduced FeNa and increased fractional potassium excretion (FeK). Hemoglobin levels improved, but hydration practices were inadequate.
population_specificity: 15 female Division 1 amateur handball players from Benin in a sub-Saharan environment.
study_duration: 10 days of tapering (total training camp duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an injury prevention training model (I-PROTECT) for youth handball players, incorporating both physical and psychological aspects, using a participatory design involving multiple stakeholders.
results_summary: The study describes the development process of the I-PROTECT model, which includes evidence-based, theory-informed, and context-specific injury prevention training and an associated implementation strategy, but does not yet report empirical results on its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Youth male and female handball players from two community clubs in southern Sweden.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 12-week circuit strength training program on physical fitness in handball players.
results_summary: The circuit strength training group showed significant improvements in performance metrics, with the largest gains in the Yo-Yo test and squat jump. The mean effect size for the experimental group was markedly higher than the control group, indicating the program's effectiveness.
population_specificity: Handball players (n = 19, divided into CT = 10 and CG = 9).
effective_dosage: Not specified (part of regular regimen replaced with circuit strength training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the correlation between body posture, postural control, and injury occurrence in male handball players, as well as the impact of playing position and NSAIDs use.
results_summary: The study found that shoulder injuries correlate with scapular height differences and vertebrae rotation, while lower limb injuries affect the Centre of Pressure (CoP). Wing players had the lowest injury risk, with pivot players most affected by lower limb injuries and wing players by shoulder injuries. No correlation was found between profession level, NSAIDs use, and body posture or postural control.
population_specificity: 91 male handball players, categorized by playing position and years of experience.

study_goal: The researchers were documenting a case of a hand injury sustained during a handball match and the subsequent diagnostic and referral process.
results_summary: The study reported a case of a right hand injury in a military cadet during a handball match, leading to suspicion of a third metacarpal fracture confirmed via fluoroscopy and radiographs, with referral for orthopaedic consultation.
population_specificity: 20-year-old right hand-dominant male military cadet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether small-sided team handball training improves cardiovascular and metabolic parameters in overweight premenopausal women, with a focus on the influence of prior handball experience.
results_summary: The study found that handball training improved VO2max, endurance performance, and body composition in participants with minimal prior experience, while those with prior experience showed cardiac adaptations like increased left ventricular mass. No significant changes were observed in muscle mass, blood lipids, resting heart rate, or blood pressure across groups.
population_specificity: Overweight premenopausal women (n=32, divided into inexperienced, experienced, and control groups).
effective_dosage: 1.6 ± 0.3 training sessions per week at 84-85% of maximal heart rate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of combined resistance training with handball-specific drills (CRT) versus resistance training without handball-specific drills (NSDT) on athletic performance in handball players.
results_summary: Both CRT and NSDT groups showed significant improvements in sprint, throwing, and jump measures, with the largest effects observed in the NSDT group for squat jump and medicine ball throw. The greatest difference between groups was seen in jump shot performance, while repeated-sprint ability showed no difference between groups.
population_specificity: 22 male handball players studying physical education.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors regarding shoulder injury risk factors and prevention in elite handball, and to evaluate the application of the OSTRC Shoulder Injury Prevention Programme.
results_summary: The majority of coaches and captains believed handball players are at high risk for shoulder injuries and supported the prevention program, but compliance was low due to time constraints and lack of player motivation. The study suggests potential for program implementation but highlights key barriers.
population_specificity: Elite handball teams (22 male and 22 female) with coaches and captains as participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the relationship between contextual factors (e.g., score, numerical balance, defensive system) and decision-making in the finalization of positional attacks in beach handball, comparing male and female categories.
results_summary: The study found that goal advantage and numerical balance significantly influenced decision-making success in both genders, with longer attack durations linked to successful performance in females and increased technical fouls in males during late-game situations. Defensive systems also impacted outcomes differently, with males showing success against any defensive system and females exhibiting more errors under pressure.
population_specificity: Beach handball players (male and female categories)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of short-term in-season weightlifting training on muscle strength, peak power, sprint performance, and ball-throwing velocity in male handball players.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in sprint and throwing performance, as well as some strength parameters, but minimal or negative effects on jump performance. The largest improvements were seen in snatch strength and 15-m sprinting.
population_specificity: Male handball players (age ~20 years, height ~1.83 m, body mass ~85 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an 8-week Nordic hamstring exercise (NHE) training intervention could improve physical performance (sprint speed, jump performance, change-of-direction, and repeated-sprint ability) in young female handball players compared to regular handball training.
results_summary: The NHE training group showed moderate improvements in sprint speed, change-of-direction, and jump performance, with trivial to small improvements in repeated-sprint ability. The control group exhibited performance decrements or trivial improvements, and between-group comparisons favored the NHE group for most performance metrics.
population_specificity: Young female handball players (mean age ~15.9 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a six-week core stability training (CST) intervention improved maximal throwing velocity and core strength parameters in female handball players.
results_summary: The CST group showed significant improvements in core endurance and isometric strength of selected core muscles, but throwing velocity (standing throw) remained unchanged. Both groups improved jump throw velocity, though the CST group's increase was slightly higher.
population_specificity: Twenty female handball players (23.4±4.4 years, 168.4±3.5 cm, 66.9±9.2 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Syzygium cumini nectar supplementation on performance, oxidative stress, muscle damage, and psychological response in young handball players.
results_summary: The study found that SC nectar reduced oxidative stress and muscle damage biomarkers (CK, LDH, MDA) and improved psychological response (mood disturbance and confusion) compared to placebo, though performance improvements (vertical jump, fatigue index) were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Elite high school national level Brazilian Handball players (n=25, age 18.6 ± 2.4 years).
effective_dosage: 10 mL/kg/day, ingested 30 min before and immediately after training sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if short-term slackline training could improve balance and neuromuscular performance in female handball players, specifically assessing task-specific versus general balance improvements.
results_summary: Slackline training improved task-specific balance (slackline standing time) but did not significantly affect general dynamic or static balance. A minor transfer effect was observed in change-of-direction performance, but no other neuromuscular improvements were noted.
population_specificity: 25 female handball players (23.7 ± 3.9 years).
effective_dosage: 12 sessions totaling 120 minutes of slackline training (single and double slacklines).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to be short-term (12 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of small-sided team handball training on body composition, osteogenic response, physical performance, cardiovascular risk factors, well-being, and motivation in young untrained women.
results_summary: The study found that handball training improved muscle mass, bone mineral density, intermittent endurance, and treadmill performance, as well as intrinsic motivation and well-being, but did not significantly affect fat mass, blood pressure, resting heart rate, or blood lipids.
population_specificity: Untrained young women aged 20-30 years.
effective_dosage: 1.7 ± 0.3 sessions per week, 70 minutes per session (4 v 4 handball).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify facilitators for integrating injury prevention training into regular routines in youth team handball by engaging stakeholders at multiple levels.
results_summary: The study identified five key clusters of facilitators, with "Understanding and applying knowledge" rated highest in importance and feasibility. Results suggest that context-specific injury prevention training and implementation plans, developed in partnership with stakeholders, are needed for effective adoption.
population_specificity: Youth team handball stakeholders (players, coaches, caregivers, administrators) from two community clubs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate behavioral patterns in elite handball matches based on location (home vs. away) to understand home advantage.
results_summary: The study identified distinct T-patterns in home (1085) and away (1242) matches, with effective launches linked to specific categories. Location significantly influenced match outcomes, with home teams winning 69% of cases compared to away teams (16%).
population_specificity: Thirty-nine European elite handball matches (N = 39).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of plyometric and standard jump training on physical performance in young male handball players.
results_summary: Both training protocols improved fat mass, maximal power, and aerobic power at the anaerobic threshold, but plyometric training did not provide additional benefits over standard jump training for jumping performance or maximal power in the RSA test. Aerobic capacity and fatigue index remained similar under both training conditions.
population_specificity: Young male handball players (n = 26, aged not specified).
effective_dosage: 15 sessions of plyometric or standard jump training (ground contacts matched).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the physiological responses of young trained handball players 24 hours after static stretch (SS) or dynamic stretch (DS) protocols.
results_summary: The study found that both SS and control conditions led to knee extensor deficits, while DS impaired knee flexor performance at 60°/s but improved knee flexor force and power at 300°/s compared to control. DS counterbalanced testing-induced knee extensor impairments but may have caused minor muscle damage in knee flexors for at least 24 hours.
population_specificity: Eight young male elite handball players (age 16.1±5.1 years).
effective_dosage: SS (2 repetitions of 75s per leg), DS (5 repetitions of 30s per leg).
